Chapter 11: Distinguishing Karma, part 4, section 11. As explained above, there are five kinds of fruits. How many fruits does each karma have?
Verse:
Karma with outflows on the path of elimination has five fruits in full,
Karma without outflows has four, namely only excluding the karmic maturation,
The remaining wholesome and unwholesome with outflows also have four, excluding the disjunction,
The remaining without outflows and indeterminate have three, excluding the above excluded.
Discussion:
The path that can realize elimination and that can eliminate afflictions is called the path of elimination, which is the uninterrupted path.
This path is of two kinds, namely with outflows and without outflows.
Karma with outflows on the path has all five fruits:
The corresponding fruit means that in one's own stage, subsequent similar dharmas are equal or increased.

The result of retribution is the agreeable retribution attracted by the path of elimination in its own stage.ğŸ”½The result of disentanglement is the as a result of the power of this path, the passions that are eliminated are realized as the unconditioned result of discernment.
The result of conscious effort is the dharmas of possession and the elimination that are attracted by the path.
The term possession refers to dharmas that are born together.
The term elimination refers to the path of liberation that is born immediately after.
The term cultivated refers to future cultivation.
Elimination refers to the cessation resulting from discernment, which is realized through the power of the path.
The dominant result is as follows: There is an opinion that it is all conditioned dharmas other than one s own nature, excluding those born previously.
There is another opinion that
elimination should also be a dominant result of the path, because the power of the path is able to realize it.

If this is so, why is it that in the Abhidharma it is said that the result of conscious effort of the elimination of the ten propensities of the desire realm is the result of the perseverance for the knowledge of the dharma of suffering, and it is never said that it is a dominant result?

It is not the case that because something is not mentioned, it is not a result of that action. Because the same text says that the knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering is the homogeneous and dominant result of the patience that is the knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering, etc., and never says that it is the result of the knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering.

Although in reality the knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering is the dominant result of the patience that is the knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering, it is not mentioned because its meaning is already established.
This is also the case here. When the homogeneous result is mentioned, the dominant result is already included.
It is not only that which can be produced that is a dominant result, because it is said that non-analytical cessation is the result of mind. Apart from this, there is no other meaning of result.
In the path of liberation, pure path karma only has four results, excluding the result as retribution.
The remaining impure good and bad karma also have four results, excluding the result of dissociation. Because it is different from the path of liberation, it is said to be the remaining.
The remaining words that follow should be explained in the same way.

That is, the remaining pure and indeterminate karma only has three results, excluding the results that were previously excluded, namely, excluding the previously excluded results of retribution and dissociation.
Having generally distinguished that actions have results, next we discuss the characteristics of actions that have results. Among them, we first discuss the three types of good, etc., actions.
Verse:
Good, etc., with regard to good, etc., the first have four, two, and three,
The middle have two, three, and four, the last have two, three, and three results.
Discussion:
The last mentioned all have the word respectively, which shows the meaning that pervades the previous section as appropriate.
Moreover, good, bad, and indeterminate actions each take good, bad, and indeterminate dharmas as their results, as appropriate.
The number after each should be understood in the same way.
That is, good actions take good dharmas as four results, excluding the ripening result.
They take bad dharmas as two results, namely the human effort and dominant results.
They take indeterminate dharmas as three results, excluding the outflow and disjunction results.
Bad actions take good dharmas as two results, namely the human effort and dominant results.
It has three fruits with regard to unwholesome [karma]: excluding the karmic maturation and disconnection fruits.
It has four fruits with regard to indeterminate [karma]: excluding the disconnection fruit.

The homogeneous cause means that all unwholesome karma abandoned by seeing suffering and the universal unwholesome karma abandoned by seeing the cause are the homogeneous cause of the indeterminate dharmas such as the views of attachment to an extreme in the desire realm.
Later indeterminate karma has two fruits with regard to wholesome dharmas: the human effort fruit and dominant fruit.
It has three fruits with regard to unwholesome [karma]: excluding the karmic maturation and disconnection fruits.
The homogeneous cause means that the indeterminate karma such as the views of attachment to an extreme is the homogeneous cause of the five classes of unwholesome [karma].
It has three fruits with regard to indeterminate [karma], like unwholesome [karma].
Having explained the three natures, we will now explain the three times.
The verse states:
The past has four fruits with regard to the three, the present also has the same.
The present has two fruits with regard to the present, the future has three fruits with regard to the future.
The treatise states:
Past, present, and future three karmas each take the past, etc., as their fruits as appropriate.
The specific means that past karma takes dharmas of the three times each as four fruits, excluding disjunction.
Present karma takes future as four fruits, as explained before, and takes present as two fruits, namely, human effort and dominant.
Future karma takes future as three fruits, excluding the homogeneous and disjunction.
It is not said that later karma has earlier fruits, because earlier dharmas are definitely not the fruits of later karma.
Having explained the three times, we will now explain the various stages.
The verse says:
The same stage has four fruits, different stages have two or three.
The treatise says:
In the various stages, following which stage's karma, it takes dharmas of the same stage as four fruits, excluding disjunction.
If it is contaminated, it takes dharmas of different stages as two fruits, namely, human effort and dominant.

If it is pure, it takes dharmas of different stages as its three fruits, excluding the karmic maturation and disconnection fruits. Because it does not fall into the realms, it does not block the homogeneous cause.
Having explained the various stages, we will now explain the three types of learners, etc.
The verse states:
Learners have three each in the three, non-learners have one, three, and two,
Non-learners and neither-learners-nor-non-learners have two each and five fruits.
The treatise states:
The three types of karma of learners, etc., each take the three dharmas as their fruits in order.

The specific means that learner karma takes learner dharmas as its three fruits, excluding the karmic maturation and disconnection fruits. Taking non-learner dharmas as its three fruits is also the same.
Taking neither as its three fruits, excluding the karmic maturation and homogeneous causes.
Non-learner karma takes learner dharmas as its one fruit, which is the dominant fruit.
Reason dictates that it should be two, adding the homogeneous cause.
Taking non-learner dharmas as its three fruits, excluding the karmic maturation and disconnection fruits.
Taking neither as its two fruits, which are the human effort fruit and the dominant fruit.

Non-two actions take the two fruits of the learned dharmas as their fruits, namely the human fruit and the dominant fruit.ğŸ”½Taking the two fruits of the unlearned dharmas as their fruits is also like this.
Taking the two fruits of the neither-learner-nor-unlearner dharmas as their fruits is also like this.
Having explained the learned and so forth, we will now explain the three types of karma such as that which is to be eliminated by seeing.
The verse states:
The three types of karma such as that which is to be eliminated by seeing each have three fruits.
The first has three, four, and one fruit. The middle has two, four, and three fruits.
The last has one, two, and four fruits. They should be understood in sequence.
The treatise states:
The three types of karma such as that which is to be eliminated by seeing each have three dharmas as their fruits.

The specific explanation is that the first, karma to be eliminated by seeing, takes the dharmas to be eliminated by seeing as its three fruits, excluding the karmic maturation and the disjunction fruits.
It takes the dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation as its four fruits, excluding the disjunction fruit.
It takes the dharmas to be eliminated neither by seeing nor by cultivation as its one fruit, namely the dominant fruit.
The middle, karma to be eliminated by cultivation, takes the dharmas to be eliminated by seeing as its two fruits, namely the human fruit and the dominant fruit.
It has four fruits excluding the disconnection fruit.
It has three fruits excluding the homogeneous and the karmic maturation fruits.
The last, i.e., the non-defined action, has one fruit, i.e., the dominant fruit, with regard to the dharmas to be abandoned by the path of insight.
It has two fruits, i.e., the human effort fruit and the dominant fruit, with regard to the dharmas to be abandoned by the path of cultivation.
It has four fruits excluding the karmic maturation fruit with regard to the dharmas not to be abandoned.
The general rule is that the above should be applied to all the above cases.
Having discussed the various actions, we should ask:

What are the three actions mentioned in the Abhidharma treatise, i.e., the action that should be done, the action that should not be done, and the action that is neither to be done nor not to be done?
Verse:
Defiled action should not be done. Some say it also violates the rules.
The action that should be done is the opposite of this. The third is contrary to both.
Treatise:
Some say that defiled bodily, verbal, and mental actions are called improper action because they arise from improper attention.
Other masters say:
Bodily, verbal, and mental actions that violate rules of propriety, even if they are not defiled, are also improper action, because they do not conform to worldly rules of propriety.

Bodily actions that are nondetermined and nondefiled, such as standing, walking, eating, and drinking, etc., that do not conform to worldly etiquette are all called bodily actions that violate rules of propriety.

Verbal actions that are nondetermined and nondefiled, such as speaking at the wrong time, etc., and the actions of the doer, etc., that do not conform to worldly etiquette are all called verbal actions that violate rules of propriety.
The two kinds of volition that instigate these actions are called mental actions that violate rules of propriety. These and defiled actions are called improper action.
Proper action is the opposite of this, and both violate the former two and are the third kind of action.
If we rely on the conventional, the latter is also possible.
If we rely on the ultimate, the former is good.
That is, only good action is called proper action, only defiled action is called improper action, and the indeterminate action of body, speech, and mind is neither proper nor improper action.

However, not all improper actions are included in evil actions, because only the unwholesome is included in the nature of evil and is called evil action. That which brings about a desirable result is called good action, and that which brings about an undesirable result is called evil action.
Although the indeterminate action of body, speech, and mind is improper action, it is not included in evil action, because the results it brings about are neither desirable nor undesirable.
Now, we should further consider this:ğŸ”½Is it that by one action only one birth is brought about, or is it that many births are brought about?
Also, is it that one birth is brought about by one action only, or is it that many actions bring about one birth?
A verse says:
One action brings about one birth, many actions bring about perfection.
The treatise says:
If one relies on the correct principle, one should definitely say that only one birth is brought about by one action.
The phrase â€œin this rebirthâ€ indicates the similarity of life, because one is said to be born only after obtaining a similar life.
If it is said that one rebirth is led by many actions, or that one action can lead to many rebirths, what error is there in these two statements?

First, there is an error, because if the result of action ends in one rebirth and the result of another action arises, there should be death and rebirth, because the results of action are different, or else there should be no death in many rebirths, because the ending of the result of action is like one rebirth.
Both are erroneous, because there should be many deaths and rebirths in one prior existence, or else there should be no death or rebirth in the interim until nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder.
Why is it that in one realm and one place, when the result of a different action arises, there is death and rebirth, but when the result of a different action arises, there is no death and rebirth?
It must be established that when the result of one action ends, the result of another action arises, there is death and there is rebirth.

Also, if it is admitted that one life is definitely attracted by many kinds of action that is created and increased, then it is certain that there would be no premature death, or else, one would not experience the results of action and would abandon it forever.
This has already been explained.

What has already been explained?ğŸ”½It has been said that there is no necessary relationship between the time of the retribution of action and the time of the experience of the retribution. Also, it has been said that there is no necessary relationship between the time of the action and the experience of the retribution.ğŸ”½If it is claimed that some births are attracted by many kinds of action, some definite and some indefinite, or that some births are attracted by many kinds of definite action, and for this reason there is premature death and there is also completion of the life span, this is not reasonable, because there is no certainty as to whether the retribution of action is definite or indefinite as to the time of retribution.
If there is a class of beings in whom the action that should produce the retribution of a certain period of life, whether in middle age, old age, or a certain stage, is indefinite, how is this?

It is impossible for there to be a later existence without a prior existence, because the results of actions must be experienced in a definite way, since the results of actions must be experienced in a definite way.

However, there is no definite principle here that would cause the actions of a prior existence to definitely result in the experience of results, or that would cause the actions of a later existence to result in the experience of results in an indefinite way. Therefore, one life is not attracted by many actions.
There is also a fault in the later position, because one action would attract many lives, and the definite time and action would become confused.
This is not confused, as has already been explained.
Therefore, one action cannot attract many lives.
If that is so, why did the Venerable Aniruddha say:

I remember that once, in one time, I gave a single meal of alms to a superior field of merit. As a result, I was reborn seven times in the Heaven of the Thirty-three Gods, seven times as a wheel-turning sage king in the human realm, and finally was reborn in the great ÅšÄkya family, with abundant wealth and much happiness.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas have already explained this statement:
One act of giving food as a basis gives rise to many superior thoughts and vows, which can lead to many different states of ripening.
Therefore, it is said that the ripening of one act of giving food.

It should not be that ripening can again lead to rebirth. It is only to show that many states of ripening are attracted by the many thoughts and vows that arise based on the single object of giving food. Therefore, it is said this way.

Or it is said in order to show the initial basis. By that one karma, one is reborn in a life of great nobility, much wealth, and wisdom from past lives. Riding on this, one further creates merit that leads to other rebirths. In this way, it continues until the final body, born in a wealthy and noble family, attaining the ultimate fruit.

There is a case where, based on one kÄrá¹£Äpaá¹‡a, one diligently seeks interest and achieves a thousandfold return. It is said, I originally had one kÄrá¹£Äpaá¹‡a, and now I have become greatly wealthy and noble.
Therefore, one karma only leads to one rebirth.
Although it is said that one rebirth is led by one karma, it is allowed that perfection is accomplished by many karmas.
It is like a painter who first sketches the outline with one color and then fills in the various colors.
In this analogy, does the one color stand for one type of karma or one instant of karma?

If it stands for one type, it contradicts the principle of this school, because it cannot be said that one karma leads to one birth based on one type, because a type must be many, and it is unreasonable for many to lead to one birth.
If it is said that the one color is analogous to one instant, and one instant cannot sketch the outline, then the analogy established is unable to prove anything.
Now we see that in this analogy, the one color stands for one type of karma.
How can leading karma be established based on type?
Because leading karma for one realm has many kinds.

This statement intends to show that within one type of karma, only one instant leads to the continuity of the same type or different types, and many instants of karma can perfect it, therefore it is said to be many.
Therefore, it is reasonable to say that it is like a painter who first sketches the outline with one color and then fills in the various colors.

Therefore, although all people have the same human body, some have complete limbs, faculties, shape, size, complexion, strength, and adornments, while others have many deficiencies. Is birth only caused by karma, or can it be caused by other factors?
No, all karma has the power to attract and complete birth. However, karma that is strong can also attract and complete birth, while karma that is weak can only complete birth but not attract it.
What are the natures of these two types of karma?
Verse:
The two mindless samÄdhis can only obtain, not attract other common destinies.
Treatise:
Although the two mindless samÄdhis have retribution, they do not have the power to attract common destinies, because they do not coexist with karma.
All unwholesome and wholesome contaminated attainments also do not have the power to attract common destinies, because they do not have the same fruit as karma.
The remaining unwholesome and wholesome contaminated dharmas can both attract and complete [birth].
The BhagavÄn said that there are three grave obstacles, namely the obstacle of karma, the obstacle of afflictions, and the obstacle of retribution.
What are the natures of these three obstacles?
Verse:ğŸ”½The three obstacles are the uninterrupted karmas,
and the frequently occurring afflictions,
and all evil destinies, the northern continent, and the heaven of non-perception.
Commentary:
As for the nature of the obstacle of karma, it refers to the five heinous acts:

1) killing one's mother, 2) killing one's father, 3) killing an arhat, 4) disrupting the harmony of the Saá¹…gha, and 5) maliciously drawing blood from a buddha.ğŸ”½As for the nature of the obstacle of afflictions, it refers to the frequently occurring afflictions. If the lesser afflictions occur frequently, even if one wishes to subdue and eliminate them, it is difficult to find an opportunity. Because they gradually cause the arising of the greater afflictions, which are difficult to subdue, they are also called obstacles.
If the greater afflictions do not occur frequently, the path of antidotes can easily find an opportunity to arise. Even if they are extremely intense, they are not included in the obstacles.

Although all sentient beings bound by the bonds of the realm of desire equally possess all passions, the differences in the actual activity of the passions are obstacles. Therefore, in the passions, the one that is most frequently activated, whether superior or inferior, is called the obstacle of the passions.
The substance of the obstacle of retribution is the three evil destinies in their entirety and a part of the good destinies, namely, the northern continent Uttarakuru and the mindless celestials.
Why is it called an obstacle?
It is able to obstruct the holy paths, the equipment for the paths, and the separation from passions.
It is not only the substance of the obstacle of action that is uninterrupted, but all actions that are certain to obstruct the seeing of the truth should be categorized as the obstacle of action.

That is, there are actions that are done and increased that are able to summon the evil destinies, birth from eggs, birth from the womb, birth as a woman, birth as a human or celestial being, or the eighth existence in the realm of form, etc., and also summon the great Brahma heaven, and action that is experienced after a change in the mode of existence, or one or two births in the realm of form or the formless realm. Those who have these are all without entry into the principle of the seeing of the truth.
Why is it not said that this is categorized as the obstacle of action?
Because in this class there is no certainty.
That is, in these kinds of actions, there are strong conditions that can cause them to be turned away from, and they do not obstruct the holy path and the requisites of the path.

Although there are some minor actions that cannot be turned away from, they are not established as obstacles, because the category of immediate retribution cannot be turned away from. Therefore, only these are established as karmic obstacles.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say that these five causal conditions are easy to see and easy to know, and are called karmic obstacles, namely, place, realm, rebirth, fruit, and individual.
Place refers to the fact that these five are definitely the places where mothers, etc. are born.
Realm refers to the fact that these five definitely lead to the realm of hell.
Rebirth refers to the fact that these five definitely lead to rebirth in the immediate next life and produce retribution.
Fruit refers to the fact that these five definitely lead to undesirable fruits.

Individual refers to the fact that these five heinous crimes are committed by individuals with heavy afflictions and evil conduct, and it is commonly understood that such individuals are capable of harming their mothers, etc.
Other actions are not like this, and are not established as obstacles.
The other obstructions should be understood in the same way.
Among these three obstructions, the most serious is the obstacle of the passions, because it can generate karma and karma generates its results.
Other masters say:
The two obstructions of passions and karma are the most serious, because one who possesses them cannot be cured even in the second lifetime.
What is the meaning of â€œimmediacyâ€?
This means that the action of immediate retribution necessarily produces results in the next life and there is no other karma whose results are to be experienced in the next life that can intervene.
There is an opinion that

the person who commits an action of immediate retribution definitely falls into hell from this life and does not transmigrate through any other realm. Because there is no other realm that can intervene, it is called immediate.

It is called immediate because it has immediacy, that is, it is called immediate because it is united with an immediate dharma, just as one is called a Å›ramaá¹‡a because one is united with the dharma of a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Which realms among the five destinies have these three obstructions?
The verse says:
There is no immediate retribution in the other continents, among the Uttarakurus, etc.,
because there is little gratitude and shame there. The other two obstructions are found in the five destinies.
The treatise says:

Not all destinies have all obstacles. For example, the uninterrupted karma exists only in the three continents of humans, not in Uttarakuru or other destinies or realms. Within the three continents, it exists only for women and men, not for eunuchs, etc., just as there is no evil morality.
Some say:
Because parents have little kindness toward them, and they have little shame toward their parents.
This means that their parents give birth to them with incomplete bodies and love them little.
And because they are weak, it is said their kindness is little.
Their shame and remorse toward their parents is also weak. Only when they destroy heavy shame and remorse do they touch the sin of immediate retribution.
However, the elder says:
If they harm their mother, etc., they also commit the sin of immediate retribution.
How could such a foolish person, who does what should not be done, be allowed to be reborn in the Tuá¹£ita Heaven?
How could it be that only humans who do what should not be done are not reborn in that heaven? They would definitely be reborn in hell.
Therefore, although they are questioned, their words are contrary to reason. They foolishly make this statement without any thought.
Moreover, they themselves question:
Animals and so on also kill their parents, so why is it not an immediate retribution?
He himself explains:
Because their cognitive faculties are inferior, because their thoughts change and deteriorate, and because their love is thin.
Isn't it possible that these causes also exist for fans and so on? Therefore there is no immediate retribution.
Even if we admit that those species have the sin of immediate retribution, it is not what the elder says to make few people know. Therefore what I hold is good in principle.
If someone kills the parents of a non-human, they also do not commit a heinous crime, because they have little kindness and shame.
That is to say, they have no kindness towards their child like humans do, and the child has no human shame and conscience towards them.
It has been explained that the obstacle of karma only exists in the three continents of humans. The other obstacles should be known to exist in all five destinies.
However, the obstacle of afflictions is found everywhere.
If the obstacle of retribution is completely in the three evil destinies, humans are only in the northern continent, and gods are only in the non-percipient heaven.
Isn't it that in the three continents, the bodies of fans and so on are not vessels for the holy path, so they are included in the obstacle of retribution?

There is no such principle, because in those realms, the continuity of the same kind of existence is drawn by the karma that attracts rebirth there, and one can become male or female and become a vessel for the holy path. Only in the three evil destinies, the mindless state, and Uttarakuru is it absolutely impossible to realize the holy path, and therefore only there is the obstacle to the results of karma established.
Some say that those realms belong only to ordinary beings, while the other realms may be shared with saints, and therefore they are not included in the obstacle to the results of karma.
Among the three kinds of obstacles explained above, the five heinous crimes are said to constitute the obstacle of karma. What is the nature of the five heinous crimes?
First, the elder monks say:
They have the nature of the three kinds of karma. Bodily karma and verbal karma each alone can attract the results of karma.

This principle is difficult to establish, because it is only mental karma that is weighty in its effects, and therefore it is accepted that it can attract the most excellent results of karma. This is extremely far-fetched.
What is meant by far-fetched?

You have already admitted that volition that occurs in dependence on body and speech is called bodily and verbal action. Now if you admit that the nature of the action of immediate succession is mental action, then the volition that arises for a moment to commit patricide would be the action of immediate succession.
Also, you say that the action of mental action is grave, and you admit that it can produce a special retribution. This is mere idle speculation, because it contradicts your own tenets.

If a volition moves and emits body and speech, this volition can be said to be the grave action that is done. However, it cannot be said to be mental action, because it occurs in dependence on the two doors of body and speech.
If a volition cannot move and emit body and speech, you admit that it is mental action, but the action that it does is not grave. How can you say that the action of mental action is grave?

If you say that the two volitions that move and emit body and speech are mental action, and the grave action that is done by volition is called the grave action of mental action, this is also unreasonable, because the action is not grave.

If only volition does not constitute bodily and verbal action, and the grave action that is done by mental action is drawn out by mental action, how can it be said that the grave action that is done is accomplished?
Because it is said that the action of body and speech is manifest and active, and therefore heavy, but the volition of mental action is not.

If you say that the action of body and speech is heavy because the volition that produces it is heavy, and therefore you say that the action of body and speech is heavy, then the volition that produces the action of body and speech is heavy because the result of the action is heavy. Therefore, the action of body and speech should be called heavy. If this is so, then there would be a great error.

Also, the action of body and speech is not the cause and result of the volition of mental action, and therefore they do not together produce retribution. Do not say that the action of body and speech is the cause and result of the volition that precedes it, and therefore they together produce retribution. If this is so, then there would be the error of not being loved.
Also, you previously said that the evidence for this cause is the difficulty in establishing that the action of body and speech alone produces retribution. What is the meaning of these words?
Do you say that it is together with the action of body and speech that produces retribution, and that therefore they are the same in substance?

The volition that is separate from the mind is also difficult to establish as that which produces retribution. Therefore, you should admit that the mind is the substance of the uninterrupted stage, or that the substance is volition.
Moreover, you should investigate and explain why mental action is uninterrupted. For example, why does the thought of killing oneâ€™s mother lead to birth in hell?
Is it due to the thought of reflection or the thought of the path of action?
If it is due to the thought of reflection, how can it definitely lead to birth in hell without any harm to the mother?
If it is due to the thought of the path of action, how can it be said that only bodily action and speech are able to bring about results?
Because the results are not taken up by the thought of reflection.

Moreover, they themselves admit that the thought of reflection precedes and the thought of the path of action follows. The former is mental action and the latter is bodily and verbal action. The time and form of each are different when compared to each other. How can it be said that only bodily action and speech bring about retribution?
This principle is difficult to establish, so what they say is outside the holy teachings.
However, the definitive meaning of what I hold to is stated in verse:
Among these five uninterrupted offenses, four are bodily actions and one is verbal action.
Three are killing, one is false speech, and one is the preparatory stage of killing.
The treatise says:
Among the five heinous crimes, four are bodily actions and one is verbal action;
Three are killing, one is the fundamental path of action of false speech, and one is the preparatory path of action of killing, because the body of the TathÄgata cannot be harmed.
The heinous crime of schism in the Saá¹…gha is false speech. Since it is false speech, why is it called schism in the Saá¹…gha?
It is named after the result, or because it can cause schism.
If so, what is the substance of schism in the Saá¹…gha?
Who accomplishes it, the one who causes the schism or the one who is caused to schism?
A verse says:
Schism in the Saá¹…gha is non-cohesion, a non-associated compositional factor,
Without obstruction, and indeterminate. It is accomplished by the Saá¹…gha that is split.
The treatise says:
The substance of schism in the Saá¹…gha is the nature of non-cohesion, included in the aggregate of non-associated compositional factors, and is without obstruction and indeterminate.
How can it be accomplished?
In this way, schism in the Saá¹…gha arises from false speech. Therefore it is said that schism in the Saá¹…gha is the result of a heinous crime.
The schismatic is not the one who accomplishes the schism, but the schism is accomplished by the Saá¹…gha that is divided.
What does the schismatic accomplish?
Where and for how long is the retribution of schism?
Verse:
The schismatic accomplishes the sin of false speech,
